climbs.name: War Inna Babylon
climbs.fa: FA, Bolted and Prepped by Alan Collins

content.description: Begin up a slab that never feels insecure to move on. Awkwardly facing holds lead to a stopper crux as the wall goes vert. While it seems there could be multiple options for this crux, a very small hold seems to be entirely unavoidable to crank on. After the 5th bolt, the climbing eases but the final runout for the chains makes for a gripping experience.
content.protection: All fixed yellow steel draws with steel carabiners at the chains.
content.location: 3rd route to the right of System of a Down (the arete) Follows up yellow fixed draws.

climbs.name: System of a Down
climbs.fa: FA, Bolted and Prepped by Alan Collins

content.description: The System rides straight up the eye catching arete on the left side of the wall. It is the longest, hardest, and most classic line on the wall. Start up a perplexing 5.10 slab to the base of the holdless arete. Get the first 2 bolt clipped on the arete (a challenge in its own) and begin up the blunt arete for 6 bolts of brutal power endurance.
content.location: Most left route on the Babylon walls steep right side. Goes straight up the overhanging arete off the slab below.

climbs.name: Sons of Anarchy
climbs.fa: FA, Bolted and Prepped by Alan Collins

content.description: Start up the big offsets on a seam with multiple 5.11+ cruxes till the wall steepens at the last 2 bolts. Going for the last bolt, the climbing begins to get harder until a baffling crux passing the last bolt. Then the pucker factor goes up as the holds disappear well above your protection. There is a clipping stance somewhere up there!!
content.protection: All fixed red draws. Fixed steel carabiners at the anchors as well.
content.location: 2nd route to the right of System of a Down (the arete)

climbs.name: Sabotage
climbs.fa: FA John Collins, Bolted and prepped by Alan Collins

content.description: Starts with a boulder problem passing the 1st bolt then to a no hands at the 2nd. Climb up thru the roof to the crux moves onto the face. Climbing lets up more and more after the 5th and 6th. A good pump combined with some route finding should keep the run to the anchor engaging.
content.protection: Fixed yellow draws with steel carabiners at the anchors
content.location: Fixed yellow draws on the right side of the wall. First bolt is hard to clip.

climbs.name: Powerslave
climbs.fa: FA, Bolted and Prepped by Alan Collins

content.description: Begin on the boulder start of Modern Day Hustle on Red fixed draws. After the 2nd draw, begin up the left variation as the draws change color. The climbing difficulty increases dramatically as you get further up the overhang. Intense pockets and small hard-to-find crimps lead through the crux at the last 2 bolts.
content.protection: All fixed lead draws and steel carabiners at the anchors
content.location: Start off Modern Day Hustle on the first two red Red draws, then branch out left on Powerslave fixed with yellow draws.

climbs.name: Modern Day Hustle
climbs.fa: FA, Bolted and Prepped by Alan Collins

content.description: Begin up a bouldery rounded arete onto a couple hold-less slab moves. This may be the crux for many. Then traverse up and right to the base of the overhang where theres an obvious rail under a giant pocket. Use your imagination for this move! Clip the last bolt and get ready to climb well above your last bolt for the chains.
content.protection: Fixed draws with  fixed steel carabiners at the anchors
content.location: Starts on red draws to the right of the dihedral in the center of the wall. Follows up the red draws all the way to the chains.

climbs.name: Men of Mayhem
climbs.fa: FA, Bolted and Prepped by Alan Collins

content.description: Start the climb next to a big dihedral until it ends at an overhang at the 3rd bolt. This is where the difficulty gradually increases until you reach the extremely powerful crux passing the 5th bolt. It doesn't seem to ease off until the chains are clipped.
content.protection: Fixed with blue steel draws! Fixed steel carabiners at the anchors as well
content.location: starts in a obvious dihedral in the center of the wall. Fixed with all blue steel draws.

climbs.name: Master of Reality
climbs.fa: FA, Bolted and Prepped by Alan Collins

content.description: A solid seam that gradually steepens before a powerful heartbreaking crux with limited holds  passing the last bolt. Getting to the last bolt is around 12+ finished with a cryptic 13- crux going for the chains. A good endurance route with great movement.
content.protection: All fixed with steel draws and steel carabiners at the anchor.
content.location: 1st route to the right of System of a Down (the arete). Fully equipped with blue steel draws.

content.description:
A slightly overhung wall stacked with 5.13's and a couple great 5.12-'s. The wall is characterized by technical and powerful movement on holds that are hard to figure out how to use. Most of the holds face the wrong direction, making it hard to find opposition. A good spot for those looking for a secluded day of climbing without having to sacrifice lots of quality hard routes to try, even during peak climbing season on the weekend.

 While the climbing is on par with most walls at Smith, the hike will surely detour any crowds. It can also be tricky to get reliable temps up there. The shade appears around 3pm during the middle of summer. The spring and fall are the best, but the weather is less predictable. The winter sun doesn't really hit the wall making it a bad spot for winter climbing.
